//notes: config tool on the American site has a whole lot more visual options
though configurable in length and diameter upon manufacture, we assume set dimensions and calculate the entire cover as a cylinder
these dimensions appear to be within reason for the product: 7 in. is a common suppressor length, and an average diameter between 1 in. and 2 in. would be 1.5 in.
//TODO: audit dimensions and volume (use thickness or width × height?)
//variants: variants don't account for the possible mixes of sleeve and strap colors

variants.description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  "HTP" stands for "High Temperature Python", referencing a previous model by the same company.  The inner core is rated for 3000°F, or around 1650°C.  Three Velcro straps supposed with plastic buckles allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Company logo -- "Cole-TAC", with the initial C looking like a scope reticle -- is sewn onto a leaf, just before the farthest strap.  <suppressor_cover_length>  <variant_black>

Three Velcro straps supposed with plastic buckles allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Company logo -- "Cole-TAC", with the initial C looking like a scope reticle -- is sewn onto a leaf, just before the farthest strap.  <suppressor_cover_length>  <variant_olive>

//material: while kevlar isn't clearly stated in the source, this appears to be the material of the bottom layer touching the suppressor in other models

description: A high-performance soft-sleeve suppressor cover with a simple design.  <suppressor_cover_descriptor>  <suppressor_cover_length>

variants.description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  It has a clean and unassuming design.  The cover is rated for 3150°F, or around 1730°C, making it the highest-rated cover on the market.  An elaborate system of cords allows for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Company logo -- "Cole-TAC", with the initial C looking like a scope reticle -- is sewn onto a leaf, on the side closer to the muzzle.  <suppressor_cover_length>  <variant_black>

A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  It has a clean and unassuming design.  The cover is rated for 3150°F, or around 1730°C, making it the highest-rated cover on the market.  An elaborate system of cords allows for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  Company logo -- "Cole-TAC", with the initial C looking like a scope reticle -- is sewn onto a leaf, on the side closer to the muzzle.  <suppressor_cover_length>  <variant_fde>

//weight: the listed weight appears to be incorrect
listed as 0.25 oz / in., or 0.28 g / mm
for a standard length of 7 in. = 177.8 mm, that's merely 49.784 g
instead, we reference a different model of cover from the same manufacturer, with European listings using metric measurements

description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover with rugged design.  <suppressor_cover_descriptor>  <suppressor_cover_length>

variants.description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  It has a rugged-looking, almost jury-rigged design, with Liberty's Defense logo -- a simplified figure of an archer with a large bow -- near the front of the cover.  Its mineral-based inner core is rated for 3000°F, or around 1650°C, while the Kevlar outer sleeve is rated for 2000°F, or around 1100°C.  Stainless steel cord over the sleeve allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  <suppressor_cover_length>  <variant_black>

A soft-sleeve suppressor cover.  It has a rugged-looking, almost jury-rigged design, with Liberty's Defense logo -- a simplified figure of an archer with a large bow -- near the front of the cover.  Its mineral-based inner core is rated for 3000°F, or around 1650°C, while the Kevlar outer sleeve is rated for 2000°F, or around 1100°C.  Stainless steel cord over the sleeve allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  <suppressor_cover_length>  <variant_tan>

//weight: PDF source provides a listing of weights for specific models of suppressors, because a cover is generally bespoke
to make it more generic, we can calculate an approximate weight for a 7-in. suppressor of similar construction
taking Dead Air Nomad 30 suppressor as the starting point: 7.7 oz / 6.5 in = 1.1846 oz/in × 7 in = 8.2922 oz = 235.08 g
//material: inner core is a combination of Kevlar, basalt, amorphous silica, and aluminized silica (`crystal` stands in for the minerals)

//notes: it's considered heavy due to its large intended diameter, allowing ~1.5-in. suppressors to fit
other, 'lighter' models are available for smaller-diameter suppressors
for now, we pretend that the cover could be 'tied down' to accept smaller-diameter suppressors just as easily
description: A soft-sleeve suppressor cover with a fiberglass core.  <suppressor_cover_descriptor>  <suppressor_cover_length>

Cords over the sleeve allow for a high degree of diameter adjustment.  <suppressor_cover_length>  <variant_black>

description: A rubber suppressor cover with deep grooves.  <suppressor_cover_descriptor>  <suppressor_cover_length>

variants.description: A rubber suppressor cover.  Its unique design and material offer V2 an interesting look and feel, without sacrificing performance.  On top of deep grooves molded into the cover, a flat logo of Manta Defense is printed.  <suppressor_cover_length>  <variant_black>

A rubber suppressor cover.  Its unique design and material offer V2 an interesting look and feel, without sacrificing performance.  On top of deep grooves molded into the cover, a flat logo of Manta Defense is printed.  <suppressor_cover_length>  This one has a pattern meant to look like woodland camo, but it looks like smudged dark greens instead.

notes: trim applies to the internal part of the cover, where a suppressor would be, a space that would otherwise be empty
while this model doesn't appear to fold or compress, we can assume that the extra space could be filled with smaller items
